newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Funds urged to give clearer investment advice.
newsitem.headline: Funds urged to give clearer investment advice.

text.p: International mutual funds must explain themselves better to secure appropriate investors and avoid investor disappointment, a fund management expert told an industry conference on Tuesday.

"Existing prospectus formats for many international funds seem to fail the test of reliably and adequately informing an investor about the characteristics of a fund's policies and objectives," said Simon Barclay-Brown of P.T. Jardine Fleming Nusantara Investment Management in Jakarta.

For example, Barclay-Brown said it should be clearly explained that a fund investing in Taiwanese equities could be reasonably expected to earn radically different returns from one investing in the U.S. money market or a fund invested in the Hong Kong money market at yields below the level of inflation.

In the United States, the Securities and Exchange Commission requires that at least 65 percent of a fund's assets must at all times be invested in the asset class implied by the name of the fund, Barclay-Brown said.

Rather than focusing on risk assessment measures such as standard deviation and volatility, fund managers should instead outline their investment strategies clearly to potential investors along with the individual fund manager's style.
"Hopefully this will help investors to make more informed decisions regarding the funds that they choose to invest in resulting in happier investors," he said.
